Community News
BY SUNITA HANJURA
The 74 neighborhood exhibits are a vital part of
Baltimore's annual city fair. Most of the neighborhoods surrounding the Hopkins campus will be participating in the fair this
weekend. Because the theme for this year's fair is "self-help,"
neighborhood booths will demonstrate how the communities help
themselves and the city. The Community Planning and Housing
Association will award a blue ribbon to the community organization that has sponsored the best self-help program.
Charles Village: Under the orange-and-white roofs on
Market Place between Pratt and Lombard, the weekend Fair-goer
will find a replica of an old editor's desk stacked with publications dating from various times in Charles Village history. The
booth will be run by the Charles Village Civic Association.
Hampden-Woodberry: Nearby, the booth run by the
Hampden-Woodberry Community Council(HWCC)will focus on
the Hampden Roosevelt Recreational Center, which provides
snorts facilities and activities for all ages. Built in the early
1900s. the Rec Center has served at least three generations,
according to HWCC chairman Edward Peacock. While the Rec
Center is supported by city funds, private organizations and area
residents play a large role in providing the financial support and
manpower needed to run the Center. Peacock points out that "it
is just ordinary citizens who devote their time for raising money"
to keep the Rec alive.
Greater Homewood: The Greater Homewood Community Council, which serves as an "umbrella" organization--helping
coordinate the efforts of some of the smaller area associations-will focus on the Action in Maturity (AIM) program for their
booth at the Fair. Run by a volunteer corps of neighborhood
residents, AIM organizes arts and crafts classes, trips, lectures and
meetings for senior citizens living in the area. The meetings
which are usually held in churches or at the Rotunda help to
unify the community and its interests. The GHCC will also be
selling bike route maps of the Baltimore area for one dollar at
their booth.
Roland Park: Letting your eye wander down the row of
booths set up by community organizations, you may catch a
glimpse of Roland Park as it appeared years ago. The oldest
planned neighborhood in the country will be "honoring its
unique status" by featuring poster prints and displays of Roland
Park as it appeared in the "good ole days." Jane Davis, a member
of the Roland Park Civic League, sponsoring the booth,said that
preservation of the architecture and old houses of the area is
important to the heritage of Roland Park.

Let's face it, crud consumed in solitude is the suppertime norm for most of
us. After a trying day, it's so much easier just to hit the Homewood Deli, or throw
some frozen macaroni and cheese in the toaster oven, than it is to put some serious
effort into producing a healthy meal.
Well, it doesn't have to be that way. Somewhere out there in your schedule
are people who have the same crazy hours that you do, and they, too, have to eat
What follows is the tale of my liberation from the crud circuit, and of the people
who made it all possible.
it all started one afternoon last year during intersession. The fencing team-an odd assortment of intellectuals, near-athletes, and libertarians--was winding down
from another grueling practice.
"Hey, guys, what say we shower up and hit the Grad Club for some chow?"
someone suggested.
There was a general mumble of assent, but no one sounded too enthusiastic.
A s'olid week of meal-burgers, Weaver's frozen chicken, and not-very-ethnic pizza was
beginning to take its toll.
I had my own objections. more financial than intestinal. It was costing a
fortune to eat very badly. "Well, you can count me out," I said. "I'm gonna throw
some stuff together at home. Anyone want to join me?"
It was like magic.
"Hey, yeah, I'll bring some tofu."
"I've got some kielbassa left over from Orientation Week."
"We'll bring the National Boll..."
In a space of minutes, the Fencing Team Mobile Eating Co-op had been born.
It made so much sense that one felt like pinching oneself for not having thought of it
sooner. We all had the same late afternoon schedules. We all more or less liked each
other (this is an important consideration in an eating co-op--the sight of the person
sitting across from you should not adversely affect your enjoyment of the meal). We
all preferred eating good food with a group of friends in a nice living room to eating
either mediocre and expensive restaurant food or eating hastily slapped-together glop
alone. The only obstacles were keeping the finances straight, and making sure the
food was on time, so that everyone could get back to the library to study.
As our many friends, roommates, dinner-guests, and admirers now know,the
Fencing Team Mobile Eating Co-op was a major success. For nearly two and a half
months, before finals and the end of fencing season laid it to rest, the co-op averaged
between six and ten members at any given meal. Two members cooked each night,
as the meals moved from house to house. Generally, the cooks picked days when
they had light schedules, so that dinner was on the table by 6:30 or 7:00. There was
a spending ceiling of $3.00 per person, and instead of getting reimbursed for expenses, each person simply relied on the knowledge that he could eat comparable
fare for free on the other four weekday nights. The meals were always decent and
sometimes amazing--spaghetti and clam sauce was the most ordinary dish ever served,
and sweet and sour duck, prepared by the now-legendary David Nover, was the piece
de resistance of a surprisingly nourishing semester.
There was only one serious problem with the co-op, and indeed, it was one
that we never quite overcame. No matter how early the meal was on the table, eaten.
and cleaned up after, we never seemed to leave until 9:00. Everyone was having too
good a time. The atmosphere was treacherously convivial.
Is there a fencing team co-op out there for you? Look around at the faces
you see every day, and it may be that crud and solitude are your lot no longer.

Community News
BY SUNITA HANJURA
The 74 neighborhood exhibits are a vital part of
Baltimore's annual city fair. Most of the neighborhoods surrounding the Hopkins campus will be participating in the fair this
weekend. Because the theme for this year's fair is "self-help,"
neighborhood booths will demonstrate how the communities help
themselves and the city. The Community Planning and Housing
Association will award a blue ribbon to the community organization that has sponsored the best self-help program.
Charles Village: Under the orange-and-white roofs on
Market Place between Pratt and Lombard, the weekend Fair-goer
will find a replica of an old editor's desk stacked with publications dating from various times in Charles Village history. The
booth will be run by the Charles Village Civic Association.
Hampden-Woodberry: Nearby, the booth run by the
Hampden-Woodberry Community Council(HWCC)will focus on
the Hampden Roosevelt Recreational Center, which provides
snorts facilities and activities for all ages. Built in the early
1900s. the Rec Center has served at least three generations,
according to HWCC chairman Edward Peacock. While the Rec
Center is supported by city funds, private organizations and area
residents play a large role in providing the financial support and
manpower needed to run the Center. Peacock points out that "it
is just ordinary citizens who devote their time for raising money"
to keep the Rec alive.
Greater Homewood: The Greater Homewood Community Council, which serves as an "umbrella" organization--helping
coordinate the efforts of some of the smaller area associations-will focus on the Action in Maturity (AIM) program for their
booth at the Fair. Run by a volunteer corps of neighborhood
residents, AIM organizes arts and crafts classes, trips, lectures and
meetings for senior citizens living in the area. The meetings
which are usually held in churches or at the Rotunda help to
unify the community and its interests. The GHCC will also be
selling bike route maps of the Baltimore area for one dollar at
their booth.
Roland Park: Letting your eye wander down the row of
booths set up by community organizations, you may catch a
glimpse of Roland Park as it appeared years ago. The oldest
planned neighborhood in the country will be "honoring its
unique status" by featuring poster prints and displays of Roland
Park as it appeared in the "good ole days." Jane Davis, a member
of the Roland Park Civic League, sponsoring the booth,said that
preservation of the architecture and old houses of the area is
important to the heritage of Roland Park.

Let's face it, crud consumed in solitude is the suppertime norm for most of
us. After a trying day, it's so much easier just to hit the Homewood Deli, or throw
some frozen macaroni and cheese in the toaster oven, than it is to put some serious
effort into producing a healthy meal.
Well, it doesn't have to be that way. Somewhere out there in your schedule
are people who have the same crazy hours that you do, and they, too, have to eat
What follows is the tale of my liberation from the crud circuit, and of the people
who made it all possible.
it all started one afternoon last year during intersession. The fencing team-an odd assortment of intellectuals, near-athletes, and libertarians--was winding down
from another grueling practice.
"Hey, guys, what say we shower up and hit the Grad Club for some chow?"
someone suggested.
There was a general mumble of assent, but no one sounded too enthusiastic.
A s'olid week of meal-burgers, Weaver's frozen chicken, and not-very-ethnic pizza was
beginning to take its toll.
I had my own objections. more financial than intestinal. It was costing a
fortune to eat very badly. "Well, you can count me out," I said. "I'm gonna throw
some stuff together at home. Anyone want to join me?"
It was like magic.
"Hey, yeah, I'll bring some tofu."
"I've got some kielbassa left over from Orientation Week."
"We'll bring the National Boll..."
In a space of minutes, the Fencing Team Mobile Eating Co-op had been born.
It made so much sense that one felt like pinching oneself for not having thought of it
sooner. We all had the same late afternoon schedules. We all more or less liked each
other (this is an important consideration in an eating co-op--the sight of the person
sitting across from you should not adversely affect your enjoyment of the meal). We
all preferred eating good food with a group of friends in a nice living room to eating
either mediocre and expensive restaurant food or eating hastily slapped-together glop
alone. The only obstacles were keeping the finances straight, and making sure the
food was on time, so that everyone could get back to the library to study.
As our many friends, roommates, dinner-guests, and admirers now know,the
Fencing Team Mobile Eating Co-op was a major success. For nearly two and a half
months, before finals and the end of fencing season laid it to rest, the co-op averaged
between six and ten members at any given meal. Two members cooked each night,
as the meals moved from house to house. Generally, the cooks picked days when
they had light schedules, so that dinner was on the table by 6:30 or 7:00. There was
a spending ceiling of $3.00 per person, and instead of getting reimbursed for expenses, each person simply relied on the knowledge that he could eat comparable
fare for free on the other four weekday nights. The meals were always decent and
sometimes amazing--spaghetti and clam sauce was the most ordinary dish ever served,
and sweet and sour duck, prepared by the now-legendary David Nover, was the piece
de resistance of a surprisingly nourishing semester.
There was only one serious problem with the co-op, and indeed, it was one
that we never quite overcame. No matter how early the meal was on the table, eaten.
and cleaned up after, we never seemed to leave until 9:00. Everyone was having too
good a time. The atmosphere was treacherously convivial.
Is there a fencing team co-op out there for you? Look around at the faces
you see every day, and it may be that crud and solitude are your lot no longer.

heads the men's team. "This
year will be a very interesting
year. Out of last year's top
seven runners, we lost five to
graduation. We're placing great
hope in the freshmen. They will
contribute tremendously in
coming years."

a fairly good start, although it
lost to UMBC by three points
Wednesday, even with Hopkins'
Mary Copeland winning the
meet. The previous Saturday at

effort of fairly experienced
On the contrary,
runners.

run little in the past are more
than welcome to try out for the
team.

assistant coach Tom Kepple puts
the runners through a rigorous,
logical, and consistent exercise

the new track. "We're very
happy about the track." said

help in recruiting. In the past,
prospective students would look
at the old field and think it was
the practice field."

the George Mason Invitational
meet October 3 looks very
important, and according to
Green, Gettysburg is the team to
beat this year.
